messages.message: Hi there, we should talk. I've communicated with Germany at this point and I've heard from England and keen to hear your strategic thoughts on the overall picture. Where can we draw a line of DMZs? Where (if anywhere) can we work together more proactively? It's reaching a bit, but if I ever have a spare fleet would it be useful as a loaner to your lineup in the north?
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Hi there, we should talk. I've communicated with Germany at this point and I've heard from England and keen to hear your strategic thoughts on the overall picture. Where can we draw a line of DMZs? Where (if anywhere) can we work together more proactively? It's reaching a bit, but if I ever have a spare fleet would it be useful as a loaner to your lineup in the north?'.

messages.message:

That would let you either force your way in and still put one on Ionian, or force Ionian and just use one to keep tyrrhenian empty.

messages.message:
I don't see any reason you'd be inclined to make me *too* happy if I was still trying to kill you, but since I'm apparently the only one doing that last turn I don't feel any particular obligation to stick with that plan either. 

If you remove an army, I'd be happy to see that as a sign of good will!

I do want to keep my build, but get that you wouldn't want to lose a home centre long term - right? 

Simplest answer if I go back east is to sit an army in Marseilles while everyone else leaves and lets you focus north. 

Next simplest is... A Mar moving to Spain I guess and letting you reclaim Mar uncontested?

Or we could do something more aggressive, but without me in your backyard I'm sure you could make some progress against England, if that's who you're looking at?

messages.input:
Message from FRANCE:'We're really on incompatible time schedules :)
Fleets are headed north, so is Burgundy.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from France as they confirm that their fleets are indeed heading north, aligning with your plan to send your units eastward and maintaining a strategic coordination in your respective movements. Their transparency about the directions of their fleets provides clarity in planning and reinforces a shared understanding of the disengagement strategy between your respective forces.

messages.message: You may want to cover Spain.
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'You may want to cover Spain.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from France as they provide a strategic suggestion for you to consider covering Spain, indicating a potential vulnerability in that area that you could address to protect your interests and maintain control over key territories. This advice demonstrates a level of cooperation and mutual support in the game, allowing you to fortify your positions effectively.

messages.message: Cover or try to take it?
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Cover or try to take it?'.

messages.message: Same thing, mate. It's all yours as far as I'm concerned. 😀
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'Same thing, mate. It's all yours as far as I'm concerned. 😀'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from France as they express a gesture of goodwill by essentially offering you the option to take or cover Spain as you see fit, indicating a cooperative attitude and a willingness to support your strategic decisions in the game. This friendly gesture aligns with a collaborative approach to gameplay and fosters a positive dynamic between your powers.

messages.message: Alright, will do my best!
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Alright, will do my best!'.
